author: Farrah Walton
title: chevron-right
text: The Coronavirus Pandemic and learning loss is a topic often discussed, and one still impacting many students. One group of children still dealing with those difficulties are the ones who were not yet in school when the pandemic began. "He mostly just struggles in most of the aspects," said Victoria, a mom of three. "He‚Äôs just a little bit behind.‚Äù Victoria is talking about one of her sons, who was too young for school at the start of the pandemic. "He actually didn‚Äôt go through a full year of school until second grade," Victoria said. "It‚Äôs been rough but he‚Äôs finally catching up but there‚Äôs still a lot of catchup that I‚Äôve noticed.‚Äù "If you think about it, they didn‚Äôt see the facial expressions that we learned by," said Jan Wilson, a grandparent. "They were missing all of that, and I think every grandchild was affected by that." Pre-K to first graders in 2020 may have missed a critical window during which foundational skills develop, according to recent research from Curriculum Associates . "They should‚Äôve been picking up words, sounds, and reading books and reading with another adult to understand books," said Georgetown ISD Superintendent Dr. Devin Padavil. "It was during the pandemic when everyone was wearing masks." This can lead to compounded gaps in learning over time. "We have a lot of kids that are still behind on fundamental reading skills that we are working hard to catch up on," Dr. Padavil stated. "Coming out of COVID we saw the dip," said San Marcos CISD Superintendent Dr. Michael Cardona. "We knew the dip was gonna come back. COVID really took us for a loop.‚Äù ALSO| UT faculty report criticizes handling of pro-Palestine protests on campus From San Marcos CISD to Georgetown ISD, school districts we spoke with agree: that learning loss from the COVID-19 pandemic might still be around, but they have seen an increase in students‚Äô abilities to learn at pre-pandemic levels. "We have a lot of glimmers of hope and optimism when it comes to student learning," said Dr. Padavil. Research shows school and life after school get harder if a student cannot read on grade level by the third grade, according to Dr. Padavil. He said Georgetown ISD is focused on improving elementary literacy. "We have a priority to see every student read and write on grade level because we know that strong readers and writers succeed in all of their other classes," said Dr. Padavil. Over at San Marcos CISD, Dr. Cardona said progress was made last year. "The state went down in many areas, but we went up," he said. "It kind of highlights the work teachers are doing, but we have a lot of work to do still.‚Äù

[Super Mario Bros. Wonder](/Super_Mario_Bros._Wonder)( [2023](/List_of_games_by_date#2023))
- ‚ÄúHi there! Here at the Poplin Shop, we sell everything! And we accept flower coins as payment.‚Äù
- ‚Äî
[Poplin](/Poplin)vendor, [Super Mario Bros. Wonder](/Super_Mario_Bros._Wonder)
Poplin Shops in
[Super Mario Bros. Wonder](/Super_Mario_Bros._Wonder) are found throughout [Flower Kingdom](/Flower_Kingdom). The player can exchange special purple [flower coins](/Flower_coin) they collect in courses for various items. [Badges](/Super_Mario_Bros._Wonder#Badges) and [Wonder Seeds](/Wonder_Seed) can be purchased once (similar to [Power Moons](/Power_Moon) in [Super Mario Odyssey](/Super_Mario_Odyssey) before the credits), while [Standee Surprises](/Standee_Surprise?action=edit&redlink=1), [1-Up Mushrooms](/1-Up_Mushroom), and 1-Up Mushroom bundles can be purchased multiple times.
There are a total of eleven Poplin Shops set up around the Flower Kingdom. One of them is a "secret" Poplin Shop located in
[Sunbaked Desert](/Sunbaked_Desert) that sells three Wonder Seeds for varying prices of 50, 100, and 200 purple [flower coins](/Flower_coin). This shop can be accessed by going up the stairs and down the strip by the level [Break Time! Bouncy Tunes](/Break_Time!_Bouncy_Tunes?action=edit&redlink=1). Another is the Standee Shop in the [Special World](/Special_World) that, in addition to the standard Standee Surprises and 1-Up Mushrooms, sells character-specific Standee Surprises that always grant the player a standee they have not unlocked yet for that character.

author: Reinaldo Oliveros
title: Arsenal cancela el milagro y saca al Real Madrid de la Champions League
text:
El Arsenal anul√≥ el milagro del Real Madrid y derrot√≥ 2-1 con el Real Madrid para avanzar a la semifinal de la Champions League.
El conjunto londinense supo administrarse con su ventaja en el partido de ida (3-0) y aguant√≥ a un Madrid que en el Santiago Bernab√©u fue m√°s √≠mpetu que juego.
Arsenal avanza a las semifinales y se enfrentar√° al Paris Saint Germain de Luis Enrique, que avanz√≥ a la siguiente fase tras derrotar al Aston Villa.
Los Gunners se quedan como el √∫nico equipo de la Premier League entre los cuatro semifinalistas.
Las semifinales de la UEFA Champions League 2024-2025 quedar√°n de la siguiente forma: Inter Milan vs. Barcelona Paris Saint Germain vs. Arsenal Arsenal call√≥ al Santiago Bernab√©u El Arsenal lleg√≥ a la casa del Real Madrid, que buscaba recrear el escenario de las grandes remontadas, en su mayor√≠a en la Champions League.
Aunque Declan Rice, h√©roe del partido de ida con dos goles, y Bukayo Saka se encargaron de silenciar a los merengues.
En el primer tiempo quedaron las grandes pol√©micas. El √°rbitro pit√≥ un penal por agarr√≥n de Ra√∫l Asencio, pero Courtois lo detuvo ante Saka.
Real Madrid tuvo un penal anulado tras revisi√≥n del VAR tras una supuesta falta de Rice a Kylian Mbapp√©.
En el segundo tiempo, Saka tuvo su gran revancha con un pase Merino y con sutileza venci√≥ a Courtois para abrir el marcador.
Real Madrid ten√≠a que hacer 4 goles, ante un rival que nunca le hab√≠a podido marcar.
Pero el primer gol lleg√≥ gracias a un rival de la defensa con Saliba que le regal√≥ el bal√≥n a Vinicius Jr., quien la empuj√≥ en el minuto 67 y mantener la esperanza.
Con el pasar de los minutos, Arsenal supo aguantar atr√°s y en un contraataque liquid√≥ al Real Madrid.
Martinelli qued√≥ mano a mano con el portero belga y con un fuerte remate de derecha anot√≥ el 2-1 definitivo que sentenci√≥ la eliminatoria para los Gunners.
GABRIEL MARTINELLI SEALS IT FOR ARSENAL AT THE BERNAB√âU ‚ö°
ARSENAL ARE HEADED TO THE #UCL SEMIFINALS üî• pic.twitter.com/DIX4DPvID9
‚Äî CBS Sports Golazo ‚öΩÔ∏è (@CBSSportsGolazo) April 16, 2025 El Arsenal volver√° a una semifinal de Champions League por primera vez desde la temporada 2009. En aquella ocasi√≥n cayeron ante el Manchester United de Sir Alex Ferguson y Cristiano Ronaldo.
Sigue leyendo:
‚Äì Lesi√≥n de Sergio Canales tras pelea con Demichelis se complica en Monterrey
‚Äì Fallece ex-jugador de MLS de 28 a√±os tras caer de un edificio
‚Äì Gerardo Martino podr√≠a dirigir a Neymar Jr. en Brasil

author: Leah Kuntz
title: MDMA-Assisted Therapy Shows Significant Positive Response on Self-Experience in Patients With PTSD
text: Lykos Therapeutics recently received priority review of MDMA-assisted therapy for patients with PTSD. Check out the latest research update here! According to new research, midomafetamine capsules (MDMA) may enhance treatment efficacy by improving problems of self-experience that are associated with treatment resistance. In particular, MDMA-assisted therapy has shown significant positive response on the processes of self-experience in patients with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) when compared with therapy plus placebo.1 In a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multi-site phase 3 clinical trial of participants with severe PTSD, MDMA-assisted therapy induced significant positive change in the Clinician-Administered PTSD Scale for DSM-5 when compared with therapy plus placebo. Investigators evaluated the effects of MDMA-assisted therapy and therapy plus placebo on 3 transdiagnostic outcome measures, then examined how the changes in self-experience improved PTSD scores. Approximately 90 participants were randomized to receive manualized therapy with either MDMA or placebo (MDMA-assisted therapy, n = 46; therapy plus placebo, n = 44) during 3 experimental sessions. Of those participants, 84.4% (76/90) had history of developmental trauma and 87.8% (79/90) had suffered multiple traumas. Investigators visited participants 3 times in preparation and 9 times for integration therapy. Symptoms were measured at baseline and 2 months after the last experimental session using 3 different scales: (1) 20-item Toronto Alexithymia Scale (TAS-20); (2) the 26-item Self Compassion Scale (SCS); and (3) the 63-item Inventory of Altered Self-Capacities (IASC). MDMA-assisted therapy generated statistically significant greater improvement on the TAS-20, the SCS, and most IASC factors of interpersonal conflicts including idealization disillusionment, abandonment concerns, identity impairment, self-awareness, susceptibility to influence, affect dysregulation, affect instability, affect skill deficit, and tension reduction activities. The only exception was identity diffusion. As transdiagnostic mental processes of self-experience are often associated with poor treatment outcome and therapy alone may not adequately help patients with severe PTSD, MDMA-assisted therapy‚Äôs significant positive effects provide an important treatment opportunity. ‚ÄúIt is hypothesized that the MDMA lowers psychological defenses, increases self-confidence, increases empathy, increases trust, increases emotional learning, decreases anxiety and fear, and improves mood. The combination of MDMA with intensive therapy seems to create a safe holding environment for the patient to be more likely to allow these traumatic memories to surface and be consciously processed,‚Äù Psychiatric Times Editor-in-Chief, John J. Miller MD, [wrote](https://www.psychiatrictimes.com/view/you-have-to-say-hello-before-you-can-say-goodbye).2 In February 2024, the US Food and Drug Administration accepted a New Drug Application for MDMA-assisted therapy for individuals with PTSD.3 The FDA also granted priority review status to the application and set a Prescription Drug User Fee Act target action date of August 11, 2024. If approved, this will mark the first instance of MDMA-assisted therapy and psychedelic-assisted therapy. ‚ÄúSecuring priority review for our investigational MDMA-assisted therapy is a significant accomplishment and underscores the urgent unmet need for new innovation in the treatment of PTSD,‚Äù said Amy Emerson, chief executive officer of Lykos Therapeutics and developer of the investigational MDMA-assisted therapy, in a press release.4 Stay up-to-date on news related to research on promising new interventions and developments in the treatment of a wide variety of psychiatric disorders at [psychiatrictimes.com](https://www.psychiatrictimes.com/). References 1. van der Kolk BA, Wang JB, Yehuda R, et al. [Effects of MDMA-assisted therapy for PTSD on self-experience.](https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0295926) PLoS One. 2024;19(1):e0295926. 2. Miller JJ. [You have to say hello before you can say goodbye.](https://www.psychiatrictimes.com/view/you-have-to-say-hello-before-you-can-say-goodbye) Psychiatric Times. 2023;40(10). 3. O‚ÄôBrien E. FDA accepts, grants priority review of NDA for MDMA-assisted therapy for PTSD. Psychiatric Times. February 13, 2024. [https://www.psychiatrictimes.com/view/fda-accepts-grants-priority-review-of-nda-for-mdma-assisted-therapy-for-ptsd](https://www.psychiatrictimes.com/view/fda-accepts-grants-priority-review-of-nda-for-mdma-assisted-therapy-for-ptsd) 4. Lykos Therapeutics announces FDA acceptance and priority review of New Drug Application for MDMA-assisted therapy for PTSD. Lykos Therapeutics. News release. February 9, 2024. Accessed February 13, 2024. [https://news.lykospbc.com/2024-02-09-Lykos-Therapeutics-Announces-FDA-Acceptance-and-Priority-Review-of-New-Drug-Application-for-MDMA-Assisted-Therapy-for-PTSD](https://news.lykospbc.com/2024-02-09-Lykos-Therapeutics-Announces-FDA-Acceptance-and-Priority-Review-of-New-Drug-Application-for-MDMA-Assisted-Therapy-for-PTSD)

author: @UN_News_Centre
title: Gaza: UN rights experts condemn ‚Äòkilling and silencing‚Äô of journalists
text:
Gaza: UN rights experts condemn ‚Äòkilling and silencing‚Äô of journalists
[Human Rights](/en/news/topic/human-rights)
Ongoing military operations by Israel in Gaza have made it the deadliest and most dangerous war for journalists covering it ‚Äúin recent history‚Äù, UN independent human rights experts warned on Thursday.
Expressing deep concern, the
Human Rights Council-appointed experts highlighted the alarming toll on journalists and media workers in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, particularly in Gaza.
‚ÄúWe are alarmed at the extraordinarily high numbers of journalists and media workers who have been killed, attacked, injured and detained in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, particularly in Gaza, in recent months blatantly disregarding international law,‚Äù the experts
said.
The experts noted ‚Äúdisturbing reports‚Äù of attacks against media workers despite being clearly identifiable in jackets, helmets and vehicles marked ‚Äúpress‚Äù, seemingly indicating a ‚Äúdeliberate strategy‚Äù by Israeli forces to obstruct and silence critical reporting.
Dozens dead
Since 7 October, 122 journalists and media workers have lost their lives in the Gaza Strip, with many others sustaining injuries.
Four Israeli journalists were killed by Hamas on 7 October, when fighters from the extremist group which controls Gaza and other Palestinian militants, attacked Israeli communities in southern Israel.
‚ÄúWe condemn all killings, threats and attacks on journalists and call on all parties to the conflict to protect them,‚Äù they said.
Dozens of Palestinian journalists have also been detained by Israeli forces in both Gaza and in the West Bank where harassment, intimidation and attacks on journalists have increased since the Hamas terror attacks.
Courage and resilience
The experts paid tribute to the resilience and courage of media workers in Gaza, noting that rarely have journalists ‚Äúpaid such a heavy price for just doing their job‚Äù as those in Gaza now.
‚Äú[They] continue to put their own lives on the line every day in the course of duty, while also enduring enormous hardship and tragic loss of colleagues, friends and families in one of the bloodiest, most ruthless conflicts of our times,‚Äù the experts said.
They highlighted the case of Al-Jazeera journalist, Wael al-Dahdouh, who lost his wife, two children and a grandson in an Israeli bombing on 25 October. He also survived a drone attack that killed his cameraman in late December.
He lost another son, also an Al-Jazeera journalist, along with another colleague, who were killed by an Israeli drone strike targeting their car on 7 January 2024.
Possible war crimes
The experts stressed the critical importance of the right to information as a ‚Äúsurvival right‚Äù during times of conflict, on which the very lives of civilians depend, and that journalists play an ‚Äúindispensable role‚Äù as a vital source of information, and as human rights defenders and witnesses to atrocities.
‚ÄúJournalists are entitled to protection as civilians under international humanitarian law. Targeted attacks and killings of journalists are war crimes,‚Äù the experts warned.
The independent expert called on the International Court of Justice (
ICJ) and the International Criminal Court (ICC) to pay ‚Äúparticular attention‚Äù to the dangerous pattern of attacks and impunity for crimes against journalists.
Access to Gaza
The experts further urged Israeli authorities to permit journalists to enter Gaza and safeguard the safety of all journalists in the Occupied Palestinian Territory.
They called on all combatants to facilitate prompt, independent, and impartial investigations into every journalist‚Äôs killing, in accordance with international standards.
Mandate to investigate
The experts speaking out are all Special Rapporteurs, who along with other independent rights experts are mandated to monitor and report on specific thematic issues or country situations.
They work on a voluntary basis, serve in their individual capacity, are not UN staff and do not receive a salary.

author: Piri Medya A.≈û.
title: Positive progress made in Hamas-Israel negotiations: Egyptian media | Politics
text: ‚ÄúPositive progress‚Äù has been made in negotiations between Israel and Palestinian resistance group Hamas to reach a cease-fire agreement in Gaza, Egyptian state media said Sunday, but warned against believing reported details of a possible deal. ‚ÄúA high-level source confirmed that there is positive progress in negotiations regarding reaching a cease-fire agreement in the Gaza Strip,‚Äù reported Egyptian Al Qahera News. But the unnamed source added: ‚ÄúWhat has been published about the terms of the agreement in the media is inaccurate." The source confirmed that "the Egyptian security delegation is continuing its consultations with all parties,‚Äù adding that "the return of the displaced Palestinians to the northern Gaza Strip is among the terms of the agreement." Media reports said earlier that negotiations between the two sides had hit a ‚Äúdead end,‚Äù with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu insisting on invading the southern city of Rafah despite international warnings of the danger this would pose to the some 1.5 million displaced civilians there. Netanyahu reportedly faces growing pressure not to accept a deal that would lead to ending the war in Gaza and canceling plans for a military offensive into Rafah. Israel's opposition accuses Netanyahu of trying to sabotage a hostage swap deal with Palestinian group Hamas. Tel Aviv believes 134 Israelis are being held in Gaza, while Israel is holding some 9,000 Palestinians in its jails. Israel has killed more than 34,600 Palestinians since an Oct. 7, 2023 cross-border attack by Hamas in which some 1,200 Israelis were killed and around 250 hostages taken. A previous deal last November saw the release of 81 Israelis and 24 foreigners in exchange for 240 Palestinians, including 71 women and 169 children. The US, Qatar, and Egypt have tried to broker an agreement to release the remaining Israeli captives. The conflict has pushed 85% of Gaza's population into internal displacement amid acute shortages of food, clean water, and medicine, while 60% of the enclave's infrastructure has been damaged or destroyed. Israel stands accused of genocide at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), which in January issued an interim ruling that ordered Tel Aviv to stop genocidal acts and take measures to guarantee that humanitarian assistance is provided to civilians in Gaza.

Èó≠ÁúºÁõ≤ÈÄâÁöÑÂ∫ïÊ∞îÔºöËá™ÁÑ∂ÂÖâÁßëÊäÄ+ÊûÅËá¥ÂìÅ‰ª∑ÊØî ÈòÖÁû≥Êä§ÁúºÁÅØÁ≥ªÂàó‰∫ßÂìÅÔºåÂ∞§ÂÖ∂ÊòØÊóóËà∞Ê¨æ‚ÄúÊä§ÁúºÂ§ßË∑ØÁÅØ‚ÄùÔºåÂ∑≤Êàê‰∏∫Â∏ÇÂú∫‰∏äÂÖºÂÖ∑ÊùÉÂ®ÅËÆ§ËØÅ‰∏éÊ∂àË¥πËÄÖÂè£Á¢ëÁöÑÊòéÊòü‰πãÈÄâ„ÄÇÂÖ∂Ê†∏ÂøÉÊäÄÊúØ‰ºòÂäøÁõ¥ÂáªÂÆ∂ÈïøÁóõÁÇπÔºö
ÊãüËá™ÁÑ∂ÂÖ®ÂÖâË∞±Ôºö ÂÖâÁ∫øÊó†ÈôêÊé•ËøëËá™ÁÑ∂Â§™Èò≥ÂÖâË∞±ÔºåÁ°Æ‰øùÊòæËâ≤ÁúüÂÆûÈ•±Êª°ÔºåÊúâÊïàÁºìËß£Áî®ÁúºÁñ≤Âä≥„ÄÇ

author: Agencia EFE
title: Denuncian la detenci√≥n de un tercer sacerdote nicarag√ºense en las √∫ltimas 24 horas
text: El sacerdote nicarag√ºense Fernando Calero fue detenido por la Polic√≠a, con lo que suman tres los curas encarcelados en las √∫ltimas 24 horas, denunci√≥ este viernes la abogada e investigadora nicarag√ºense exiliada Martha Patricia Molina.'Polic√≠a sandinista secuestra al sacerdote Fernando Calero, p√°rroco de Nuestra Se√±ora de F√°tima (en el municipio de) Rancho Grande, (departamento de Matagalpa). Se desconoce su paradero', se√±al√≥ Molina, autora del estudio titulado ‚ÄòNicaragua: ¬øUna Iglesia perseguida?‚Äô, a trav√©s de su cuenta de la red social X (antes Twitter).Seg√∫n la investigadora, Calero fue 'secuestrado por la Polic√≠a Nacional en su parroquia' tras haber mencionado al obispo encarcelado Rolando √Ålvarez, quien preside la Di√≥cesis de Matagalpa, en una misa.'No existe una acusaci√≥n formal en contra de √©l y no se tiene informaci√≥n de su paradero', explic√≥.Calero se suma a los sacerdotes Carlos Avil√©s y H√©ctor Treminio, vicario general y tesorero de la Arquidi√≥cesis de Managua, respectivamente, que fueron detenidos el jueves por la Polic√≠a y civiles.La semana pasada, las autoridades detuvieron al obispo Isidoro Mora, a dos sacerdotes y a dos seminaristas.Ni el Gobierno ni la Polic√≠a Nacional han confirmado o negado la presunta detenci√≥n de los religiosos.El cardenal nicarag√ºense y arzobispo de Managua, Leopoldo Brenes, a√∫n no se pronuncia sobre esos arrestos.Quien s√≠ lo hizo fue el exiliado obispo auxiliar de Managua, Silvio B√°ez, a quien el papa Francisco orden√≥ dejar Nicaragua en 2019 por motivos de seguridad, quien se declar√≥ indignado por los encarcelamientos de tres sacerdotes de la Arquidi√≥cesis de Managua.
